thread.title_full: Kristaps Porzingis tension with Knicks: Pain-free and inactive | New York Post

author: Marc Berman
title: Kristaps Porzingis tension with Knicks: Pain-free and inactive
text:
Kristaps Porzingis will sit out Friday’s Garden exhibition game against Boston, but expects to return Saturday in Charlotte — unless the medical staff overreacts to his next ailment.
Though Porzingis said he was pain free, the 20-year-old didn’t practice Thursday — the lone figure standing on the sidelines while his 19 other mates mixed it up in scrimmages.
Coach Derek Fisher ruled him out for Friday because he feels Porzingis needs a legitimate practice before playing after suffering an upper left quad strain last Sunday.
Porzingis, selected fourth in the draft, said he will have a strong workout at Friday’s shootaround and hopes to be cleared to return Saturday in the second night of a back-to-back. Friday’s is the second straight game Porzingis will miss. He’s played just once at the Garden during the exhibition season.
“I can’t wait to get back on the court,’’ Porzingis said. “Hopefully I’ll play on Saturday. I’m healthy and 100 percent.’’
The Knicks want Porzingis to start at power forward this season. The 7-foot-3 rookie seems mystified why he hasn’t been able to practice when healthy and is trying to convince himself the medical staff knows best .
“It was perfect, no pain,’’ Porzingis said. “They just want to go slowly here, make sure I’m totally fine. They’re very cautious with me. I’m telling them every day: ‘I want to get back, want to get back.’ They’re taking care of me. They know what they’re doing. It’s their job.’’
The concern is Porzingis’ attempts to learn the triangle is being stifled. At the same time he is not getting a chance to adapt to the NBA’s physical play.
“I’m on the sidelines watching the practices, staying focused the whole practice so I can remember the little details,’’ Porzingis said. “I’m staying mentally prepared for when I get on the court. Game speed is different. I’m trying to take as much information as I can. I’m telling them to help me with a few things and draw the plays. It’s different when you get on the court.’’
Watching from the bench Monday against the 76ers wasn’t easy.
“I’m obviously sitting, thinking I wished I could play,’’ Porzingis said. “That’s what was in my head.’’
